entry.title: SAP HANA Cloud 概况介绍
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud 是什么？

SAP HANA Cloud 是一款数据库产品，是一个托管的数据库即服务（DBaaS），基于内存计算技术，为实时分析和智能应用提供数据处理能力

 

SAP 开发 SAP HANA Cloud 的目的是什么？

战略层面

SAP HANA Cloud 是 SAP 云战略的核心组成部分，旨在为应用提供支持，它代表了 SAP 从传统软件供应商向云供应商的战略转型。它位于技术架构的数据层，作为 SAP 云战略的基础数据平台，支撑上层的各种 SAP 应用和第三方应用 

功能层面

一方面，SAP所有业务应用都需要足够强大的数据库来保证性能和安全性，另一方面，SAP客户在开发应用时也会需要足够强大的数据库，SAP HANA Cloud 同时既为SAP应用服务，由作为独立服务直接为客户服务

SAP HANA Cloud 解决了企业在数据处理方面的核心技术挑战：提供统一的数据访问层，简化数据处理，同时整合和协调数据集成到智能应用程序中 。它填补了云端高性能内存数据库服务的功能空白。

 

SAP HANA Cloud 在 SAP 生态中的作用和应用场景

核心功能介绍

SAP HANA Cloud 提供多模型数据处理能力，包括关系型、图形、空间、向量和半结构化数据处理，以及嵌入式机器学习功能 。同时具备内存计算、列式存储、实时分析等技术特性，能够在经过验证的内存速度下处理关键任务数据。

常见使用场景

下一代应用程序数据库：为需要在大数据量上实现超快性能的下一代应用程序提供数据库支持

数据仓库和分析平台：为包括 SAP Datasphere 和自定义数据仓库在内的数据仓库提供支持，通过连接和协调分布式数据到单一、一致的数据模型来支持 SAP Analytics Cloud 等分析工具

应用扩展和现代化：扩展本地应用程序的数据存储和处理能力，例如当大量新用户加入时，或使用基于云的服务扩展现有 SAP 应用程序的功能

 

SAP HANA Cloud 与市场同类产品的区别

产品本身的强大功能

SAP HANA Cloud 具备独特的内存计算技术、多模型数据处理能力和实时分析功能。它提供了关系型数据湖处理大量数据的能力，同时享受云服务的低成本和弹性优势

与 BTP 平台的协同效应

作为 SAP BTP 的核心组件，SAP HANA Cloud 享受平台集成优势，包括统一的开发环境、自动化的软件更新、弹性扩展和服务绑定机制，开发者可以在集成开发环境中开发和建模自定义应用程序。

与 SAP 各应用的协同效应

与SAP 业务数据云BDC协同工作，与SAP生态深度集成，例如HANA Cloud可以通过虚拟表，远程表复制等方式实时获取另一个HANA数据库的数据，这样BTP上的拓展应用就可以以最低的成本获取HANA数据库的实时数据

 

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法

entry.title: CDS view I_EQUIPMENTDATA for BW extraction: Why shouldn't it be enhanced?
entry.content:
Dear all,

I have read topic Enhance Abap CDS View I_EquipmentData. It is mentioned, that the CDS view I_EQUIPMENTDATA should not be enhanced. But I cannot find this information here: Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Equipment Data.
It is just mentioned "This CDS view is modeled for usage as a DataSource in Business Warehouse. We recommend that you only use it for this purpose.".

Why shouldn't it be enhanced? We currently use it with "extend view I_EquipmentData with Z_E_I_EQUIPMENTDATA" and it works without problems for extracting data to our BW system..

Thanks & best regards,
Yvonne

entry.title: Enhancing Your Understanding of Peru's Inventory and Balance Ledger Report: Updates to Documentation
entry.content:
I’m Maitê, a User Assistance Developer in SAP Globalization, working in the financial area. As part of my role, I’m happy to share with you the latest updates to the documentation for the Peru Inventory and Balance Ledger report in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. Explore the highlights below to discover how these improvements can help with the report!

The Report

The Peru Inventory and Balance Ledger report is currently available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP S/4HANA. The report organizes general ledger balances into subledgers across fourteen electronic accounting books, following Peru's PCGE (Plan Contable General Empresarial) and SUNAT (Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administración Tributaria) requirements. 

Recent Documentation Improvements

To help you better understand the Inventory and Balance Ledger report, we have enhanced our documentation with a new page. This addition provides details on specific fields, grouped by configuration settings and characteristics. Our goal is to clarify the relationships between certain fields in the report output and the configurations made by you before running the report.

New page added to the SAP Help Portal

 

Structured Tables for Clarity

We've organized the documentation into five tables:

  • Table 1:  Fields Related to Financial Statement Version (FSV) and G/L Account Hierarchies

This table highlights fields associated with hierarchy configurations from the app Manage Global Hierarchies, focusing on Financial Statement Versions and G/L Account hierarchy types.

  • Table 2: Fields Related to Alternative Chart of Accounts (COA)

This table details fields related to the alternative COA settings used for specific legal reporting requirements in Peru.

  • Table 3: Fields Tax Number Type and Tax Number Related to Alternative Chart of Accounts (COA)

This table specifies details on tax-related fields which are associated with the alternative COA settings.

  • Table 4: Other Fields in the Report

This table provides information about other fields, explaining their data sources and how the system populates them.

  • Table 5: Optional Fields in the Report

Finally, this table lists optional fields included in our solution and explains how they are populated, though they are not required by SUNAT.

Conclusion

We really hope these documentation updates make your journey through the Inventory and Balance Ledger report easier and more efficient. You can find them in the report documentation linked below:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Inventory and Balance Ledger 
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA: Inventory and Balance Ledger

Feel free to explore these tables on the SAP Help Portal and share your questions or feedback in the comments. They are most welcome!

Last but not least, follow the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance community tag for the latest updates. 

Thank you and until next time,

Maitê Bohn

entry.title: Meeting ‘Choai’ Requirements for Japan's Consumer Products Industry
entry.content:
In Japan’s consumer products industry, business transactions often involve a complex hierarchy of partners, known as “Choai.” These hierarchies, spanning first, second, and third levels, are crucial for daily operations, particularly when creating sales orders in bulk for multiple customers. The ability to efficiently maintain and retrieve this hierarchical partner information is essential, as it directly influences downstream processes such as pricing and rebate calculations.

Using Choai Route ID in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Japanese consumer products companies use the Choai Route Master application to maintain Choai Route IDs representing specific partner hierarchies.

When creating a sales order, sales users should have the option to select a Choai Route ID, using which the system can automatically fill in customer and partner details. This will help streamline the process and reduce manual errors.

Extending the Manage Sales Order V2 application

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition supports this localization requirement through developer extensibility in the Manage Sales Order V2 application. By extending this app, companies can retrieve customer and partner data using the Choai Route ID. SAP provides essential development objects for this purpose, including:

  • Behavior Definition (R_SalesOrderTP)
  • Metadata Extension (C_SalesOrderManage)
  • Behavior Projection (C_SalesOrderManage)

These objects enable developers to tailor the application to meet the specific needs of the Japanese consumer products industry.

Implementation Guidance

Detailed, step-by-step instructions on how to extend the Manage Sales Order V2 application to meet this localization requirement are provided in the SAP Note 3607627 and the SAP Help Portal documentation  Creating a Sales Order Using Choai Route ID. 

By utilizing these tools, organizations can ensure their SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system aligns with local business practices and regulatory requirements in Japan's consumer products sector.

Feel free to explore these resources and take the next steps towards optimizing your business processes in Japan's dynamic consumer products market.

entry.title: Re: mailer correos varios correos separados por;
entry.content:
Hola

El error al intentar enviar correos a varios destinatarios utilizando punto y coma (;) o coma (,) como separador en el módulo nativo de SAP Business One

En módulos nativos —por ejemplo, envío de documentos de marketing por email— SAP B1 espera que cada destinatario sea añadido como una línea individual o mediante el selector de contactos, no como una cadena de emails separados por un símbolo.

  • Añadir cada destinatario usando el botón para agregar contactos en el panel de envío de email. No ingresar los correos manualmente todos en un solo campo.​

  • Si necesitas un envío recurrente a varios contactos, utiliza la funcionalidad de “lista de distribución” o “grupo de correos” creada desde Socios de Negocios > Definiciones > Grupos de correo electrónico y asígnala a los contactos de la empresa.​

entry.title: Re: Error during creation of business partner from ARIBA...
entry.content:
Dear Chris @Chris1973,

Greetings!

Thanks for your time and support in this issue.

Communication setting SAP_COM_0053 is available and active.

Based on current setting, Business partner is getting created without partner function. When we go for creation of business partner with partner function, we are facing this issue

Below configurations are already maintained

- Mapping of Partner role VN to vendor account group ZV01

- Maintain partner role VN in vendor partner schema SUPL. Set as unique without mandatory

- Assign partner schema SUPL to account group ZV01

- Maintain partner role VN in PO partner schema 0002. Set as unique

- Assign partner schema 0002 to PO document type NB

Kindly give more details on the below comment given by you “Ensure that Ariba’s Supplier role SUPL maps to S4H role FLVN00 or FLVN01. The partner function VN must exist in the mapping”. Where we need to maintain? And How?

As a part of payload, Partner role VN is sent with reference supplier number. Whether we need to send german language equivalent partner role code ?. Kindly clarify. If yes, what is it?

Regards

Sudharmv

entry.title: How to Swap Axes in Risk Matrix (Impact on X-axis, Probability on Y-axis) in SAP CPM Risk Management
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently working with the Risk Management module in SAP Commercial Project Management (CPM), and I have a question regarding the Risk Matrix visualization.

 

 

By default, the matrix displays Probability on the X-axis and Impact on the Y-axis. However, for our internal reporting, we need to swap the axes — that is, show Impact on the X-axis and Probability on the Y-axis.

I have a few questions:

  1. Is there a standard configuration or setting in SAP CPM or Fiori apps that allows this axis swap?
  2. If not, has anyone implemented a custom Fiori app or enhancement to achieve this?
  3. Are there any BADIs or extension points available in the Risk Matrix component that could help with customizing the layout?
  4. Would exporting the data and visualizing it externally (e.g., in SAC or Power BI) be the most practical workaround?

Any guidance, documentation links, or shared experiences would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance,
Febin DS

entry.title: Re: Remove KKBER 'Credit Control Area' from VBAK
entry.content: Opening an entry in SE16N debug edit mode would mean that KALSM entry gets editable too. This could result in 00058 error and unable to save the entry. Suggestion is rather to implement a small report to clear the unwanted KKBER entries.

entry.title: B2B Scenario Sender EDI to IDOC
entry.content:
Introduction

Hi SAP Community, In this blog post, we will explore how to implement a B2B Scenario Sender: EDI to IDOC. This blog provides a step-by-step procedure explaining the whole process in a simple manner. So let’s walk through this journey together!

First, we need to download the source and target structures (MIGs).

In my Scenario Source MIG is (EDIFACT-ORDERS) and Target MIG is (S4-IDOC Purchaseorder).

Go to Design → MIG → Message implementation guidelines → click on create

Search with EDIFACT and select (UN/EDIFACT)

 

Search with ORDERS and select purchase order as below

 

Select the required version in my case its D.93A S3

 

Select with envelope

 

Skip the sample payload upload step

 

Provide Name, Direction, Business process(it can be anything in my case I kept as
create order)

 

Click on create and MIG gets created as below

 

Now we need to download receiver MIG

Search with SAP S/4HANA On Premise IDoc and select it

 

In my case it’s (ORDERS.ORDERS05)

 

Select version as per your requirement

 

Skip the sample payload upload step

 

Provide Name, Direction, Business process(it can be anything in my case I kept as
create order)

 

Click on create and MIG gets created as below

Both Source MIG and Target MIG gets generated.


Now we need to create MAG (mapping guidelines)


Click on Design → MAG → Click on create

 

Select the source MIG

 

Select the target MIG

 

In the below screen click on create

 

MAG gets created as below

 

In MAG click on Export → SAP Cloud Integration Runtime Artifacts

 

ZIP files gets downloaded

pls unzip it.

 

Below are the files which we will use in further steps.

 

Go to Discover tab and search with ‘EDI’ and select Package EDI Integration Templates
for SAP Integration Advisor

 

My scenario is EDI to IDOC so I will be selecting EDI to SAP IDoc - Inbound as below

 

Click on download, zip file will be downloaded as below

 

Now we need to go to Design tab →Integrations and APIs → Add → Integration flow →
Upload → Select the iflow which was downloaded

 

Open the iflow which is uploaded

 

We need to upload total 4 files
1: In EDI to XML Converter upload (UN-EDIFACT_ORDERS_D93A.xsd)

2: In EDI - Qualifier Pre-Processing upload (TestingEDI_preproc )

 

3: In EDI to SAP IDoc - Mapping upload (Mapping_TestingEDI_to_TestIdoc)

 

4: In SAP IDoc - Qualifier Post-Processing upload (TestIdoc_postproc)

 

I will remove the unwanted steps (EDI Extended Validation (optional), Sender, Receiver, Validate and EDI Interchange steps)

I will use Timer to start the flow

 

I have used the EDI payload in Content modifier to test the flow in starting step.

 

Final IDOC output in body:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ZORDERS1>
    <IDOC BEGIN="1">
        <EDI_DC40 SEGMENT="1">
            <TABNAM>EDI_DC40</TABNAM>
            <MANDT>100</MANDT>
            <DOCNUM/>
            <DOCREL/>
            <STATUS/>
            <DIRECT>2</DIRECT>
            <OUTMOD/>
            <EXPRSS/>
            <TEST/>
            <IDOCTYP>ZORDERS1</IDOCTYP>
            <CIMTYP/>
            <MESTYP>ORDERS</MESTYP>
            <MESCOD/>
            <MESFCT/>
            <STD/>
        </EDI_DC40>
    </IDOC>
</ZORDERS1>
```

Once all the steps are completed then EDI will be converted to IDOC which can be sent
to the S4 system.

 

Conclusion

This method simplifies B2B integration through mapping and automation using SAP tools. It reduces manual labor and provides error-free data exchange. By executing these steps, you can manage EDI-to-IDOC scenarios seamlessly and enhance communication between your external partners and SAP system.

entry.title: Re: Calling an external web service via https using the system certificate store
entry.content: Well, can you call the according web server via browser, too? If so, you can usually easily display the web server's certificate and its chain in the browser. - There have been changes to the underlying crypto libraries in SA17 (initially OpenSSL, later SAP Common Crypto Lib) but I guess your version already uses the latter. AFAIK, the web client does not need to provide the web server's certificate itself but one that does match the issuer of the web server's certificate.

entry.title: Re: Order not found or goods movement is not permitted in...
entry.content:
Hello,

These days I faced the same issue. The problem is the mapping between the EWM inbound delivery type and the ERP delivery type:

If no mapping is maintained here, then the system determines the EL delivery type with ELN item category. In our case, we use a copy of the DIG inbound delivery for the mapping. If the system determines EL and ELN, then the production order is not populated in the LIPS table and, when posting the GR for the production order, the error arises.

Best regards,

Alberto V.

entry.title: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Introduction:

Managing API rate restrictions or avoiding backend system overloads are common problems in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). When an API receives too many requests in a short period of time, some may reject them, while others may experience significant slowdowns.

In this post, I will demonstrate how to create a dynamic delay mechanism in CPI using Groovy Script, where the sleep duration varies according to request count(header value).

Problem Statement:

  • Rate-limiting is often necessary for backend or API services.
  • Standard CPI configuration does not offer a built-in dynamic sleep/throttle feature.
  • When the load increases, developers need a lightweight way to decrease request speeds.

Solution Approach:

We can use a Groovy Script in CPI to:

1 .Read a custom header (SAP_ApplicationID in this case).

2. Transform it into an integer request count.

3. Implement adaptive delay logic with different thresholds.

Proceed with processing after the determined sleep duration.

//Groovy script
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
 
def Message processData(Message message) {
 
    def body = message.getBody();
 
    // Read SAP_ApplicationID
    def headerValue = message.getHeader("SAP_ApplicationID", String.class);
    def requestCount = 0;
 
    if (headerValue != null) {
        try {
            requestCount = headerValue.toInteger();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            requestCount = 0; // Default if not a number
        }
    }
 
    // Determine sleep time 
    def sleepTime = 0;
    if (requestCount >= 3500) {
        sleepTime = 1500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 2000) {
        sleepTime = 1000;
    } else if (requestCount >= 1000) {
        sleepTime = 500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 500) {
        sleepTime = 200;
    } else if (requestCount < 500) {
        sleepTime = 100;
    }
 
    // Apply sleep delay
    if (sleepTime > 0) {
        sleep(sleepTime);
    }
 
    message.setBody(body);
    return message;
}

How it works :

Step 1: Get SAP_ApplicationID from headers.

Step 2: Convert it into an integer(requestCount).

Step 3: Decide sleep time dynamically:

  •  ≥ 3500 - 1500 ms
  •  ≥ 2000 - 1000 ms 
  •  ≥ 1000 - 500 ms
  •  ≥ 500 - 200 ms
  •  < 500 - 100 ms

Step 4: Sleep for calculated time.

Step 5: Pass the original message forward.

Use cases:

1. For high-frequency situations, API rate restriction with shorter delays works perfectly.

2. Backend overload protection with millisecond-level throttling.

3. Testing integrations under various load conditions.

Conclusion:

This Groovy script provides a simple but effective way to dynamically throttle requests in SAP CPI based on header values. By introducing adaptive delays, you can protect backend systems, comply with API rate limits, and simulate controlled load behaviour.

entry.title: Re: Order not found or goods movement is not permitted in...
entry.content:
Hello,

These days I faced the same issue. The problem is the mapping between the EWM inbound delivery type and the ERP delivery type:

If no mapping is maintained here, then the system determines the EL delivery type with ELN item category. In our case, we use a copy of the DIG inbound delivery for the mapping. If the system determines EL and ELN, then the production order is not populated in the LIPS table and, when posting the GR for the production order, the error arises.

Best regards,

Alberto V.

entry.title: Re: Exceptional Aggregation
entry.content:
You already do have the header amount there. I guess just need to define what you need to show. Exception Agg will provide values even the dimensions are not visible also makes no sense to have the same type. You are comparing count with sum. 

So best is to use the amount, not the summed amount. Or use the summed amount you already have and ommit the item. Anycase you cannot do exception aggregation to change the summed amount for the orders. Exc. Agg is not for that. 

Some sceen shots for simple show-case: 

all dummy data / objects: 

Exc Agg for Acount and for Header_Amount

entry.title: Re: How to Register Lot Items on Physical Inventory Count...
entry.content:
Use “Manage Physical Inventory Documents” App and search for any document that might include TG21, batch 0000000003, stock type 1. Check if it was created by a scheduled job or mass processing.

Check Job Logs by going to “Job Scheduling for Physical Inventory” and review past runs. Look for any job that might have included this stock—even if it wasn’t posted.

If both the above are not solving your issue, you can raise a ticket to SAP by referencing SAP note 604993 which is for lower version and for the same issue you reported

entry.title: Re: We want to copy serial number from service order item to sales order item.
entry.content:
Hi Team,
We are developing a process to update a sales order line item with a serial number that originates from a service order via a Fiori app. We are exploring the use of the function module SERNR_ADD_TO_AU for this purpose.
The challenge we face is identifying the correct point in the process to capture the serial number from the Service Order Fiori app and pass it to the sales order.
Our goal is to create or update the following table entries correctly:
Update table SER02 with the sales order data (OBJKR, SDFUART, POSNR).
The system should then update table OBJK with the actual serial number (SERNR), referencing the key from SER02.
Could you provide suggestions on the appropriate enhancement spot, BAdI, or alternative method for capturing this data and ensuring the sales order is correctly updated with the serial number?

entry.title: Quick tip: event/task scheduling in CAP Node.js (in alpha state)
entry.content:
Quick tip: event/task scheduling in CAP Node.js (in alpha state)

This is just a quick note about a discovery I made in capire. SAP CAP (Node.js) will support task scheduling (including callbacks) for events (actions/functions are also events) in a future release. The feature is currently still in alpha state, so it may change.

The capire release notes for May 2025 mention one feature that I personally think could be extremely valuable in the future: event/task scheduling. See this section in capire for all the details. This is what it (currently) looks like:

await this.schedule("someEvent").every("2s")
this.after("someEvent/#succeeded", (data, req) => {
// do something
console.log(data)
})

This means you can set up you CAP applications to do things on a certain schedule, similar to a job scheduler. The application can emit events, or call actions/functions on its own without requiring another application or user to trigger it. I personally think this is a great addition to CAP and potentially very useful - especially if the think about AI agents that do things on their own, on a predefined schedule. This feature could be a starting point and building block for this.

Bold hypothesis: We might see CAP as the implementation foundation for (code-based) AI agents in the SAP ecosystem in the future. CAP is great for consuming (connecting) SAP systems and adding custom logic (code) to these connections. Time will tell.

Give it a try and let me know what you think! Keep in mind that this feature is still in alpha state and may change any time.

entry.title: TR Release Warning - FOT_COMMON037 during Tax Code Creation
entry.content:
Hi,

I am currently trying to create a new Tax Code for VAT  in "Define Tax Codes for Sales and Purchases " Customizing, but when I try to create the new tax code, the system show the message "Transport request DA4K900003 must be released before changes are allowed. Message no. FOT_COMMON037".

This specific Transport Request (DA4K900003) is associated with "BC Initial Scope" configuration. Before releasing the TR, I performed a consistency control, which generated a long list of warning messages, including:

Requests could not be read
No entries found. See long text.
No transport entries available for object FINSV_FICO_CURRC and type V.
Final Status of the B-Inp Session will be read; expect longer runtime
Subobject ANLAGENNR does not exist
Interval limit starts with a special character. Interval AUFTRAG INTERVAL
No transport entries available for object V_T8G30B and type V.
No transport entries available for object V_T8G41B and type V.
No transport entries available for object V_TB038 and type V.
No transport entries available for object V_TKA01_GD and type V.
No transport entries available for object V_TKA02 and type V.
No transport entries available for object V_TKA09_CL and type V.

My main concern is: What are the potential consequences of releasing this Transport Request (TR) while these warning messages are present?

Is it generally safe to proceed with the release in this context (BC Initial Scope TR), or do these warnings indicate a significant risk of missing configuration or data inconsistency that could lead to errors in the target system?

Any guidance on this particular error (FOT_COMMON037) or the warnings would be highly appreciated.

 

Thank you in advance for your insights.
Best regards,
An

entry.title: Re: Is There a Way to Add Conditional Formula for Text In...
entry.content: Thanks for the suggestion! The reason I’m looking to do this at runtime is because we have hundreds of Crystal Reports across multiple clients that use a notes field currently displayed as plain string. We're now transitioning to store these notes in HTML format, and I’d like to build a tool that can automatically update all existing reports to interpret the notes field as HTML when appropriate. Doing this manually for each report would be extremely time-consuming and error-prone. If there’s a way to apply a conditional formula to the Text Interpretation property (e.g., switch between crHTMLText and crUninterpretedText based on the field content), it would save a huge amount of effort and ensure consistency across all reports. So far, I’ve found conditional formulas for font color, borders, etc., but not for text interpretation. If anyone knows whether this is possible—or has a workaround—I’d really appreciate the insight!

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 by the Numbers: Engagement, Badges, and Top Achievers
entry.content:
Another Devtoberfest has come to an end, and the numbers tell a strong story of developer engagement and community growth. Devtoberfest 2025 saw remarkable participation from the SAP developer community, with thousands diving into tutorials, sessions, and challenges to expand their skills. I did a analysis last year so here is another look at the numbers and practical insights from this year’s event.

Participation Overview

  • Total registered members: 5,184
  • Total badge achievements: 26,633
  • Unique badges available: 106
  • Average points per participant: 2,718
  • Average badges per participant: 5.1
  • Participation levels chart:

Level Achievement Distribution

The level progression shows clear patterns in participant engagement:

  • Level 0: 4,333 participants (83.6%)
  • Level 1: 638 participants (12.3%)
  • Level 2: 64 participants (1.2%)
  • Level 3: 14 participants (0.3%)
  • Level 4: 133 participants (2.6%)
  • Active participants by level:

While most participants started their journey at Level 0, 849 participants (16.4%) progressed beyond the initial level. Notably, 133 participants reached Level 4 ("Nerdvana"), completing the most challenging content.

Top Achievers

The highest-scoring participant was @thomas_jung  with 76,200 points and 113 badges. With an efficiency of 674.3 points per badge, this reflects a completionist approach — comprehensive coverage across most available content.

Performance Strategies

Participant behavior clustered into three practical strategies:

  • Selective specialists (≥900 points per badge): Focus on high-value badges and sessions; fewer badges, high efficiency.
  • Balanced achievers (700–899 points per badge): Mix high-value activities with broader participation; steady multi-track progress.
  • Completionists (<700 points per badge): Broad participation across categories; emphasize completeness over per-badge efficiency.

Points vs. badges distribution:

Engagement Insights

Most popular content

Top earned badges:

  1. Devtoberfest 2025 Participant — 5,182 achievements
  2. Create Database Table and Generate UI Service — 719
  3. Create an ABAP Database Table and Relevant ABAP Dictionary Objects — 617
  4. Create an ABAP Cloud Project — 553
  5. Enhance the Business Object Data Model and Enable OData Streams — 515

Top least earned badges:

  1. "Tooling Week 4" - 36 completions (0.7% participation)
  2. "Developer Advocates Discuss: Developer Tools" - 38 completions (0.7% participation)
  3. "Tooling Week 3" - 54 completions (1.0% participation)
  4. "Data & AI, Week 4" - 63 completions (1.2% participation)
  5. "Bugtoberfest - SAP Build" - 64 completions (1.2% participation)

Highest point value badges

  • Scavenger Hunt — 3,000 points
  • Techtoberfest SAP Puzzles — Cryptic — 2,000 points
  • Weekly Session Validations — 1,200 points each

Year-over-Year Comparison

Comparing 2025 to 2024 reveals notable shifts in both volume and depth of engagement.

Metric20242025Change
Total participants~4,0005,182+29.6%
Total badge achievements~9,00026,633+196%
Available badges159106-33.3%
Average points~1,5002,718+81.2%
Level 4 achievers163133-18.4%

 

 

Thank you to developer advocates who organized the Devtoberfest 2025!
See you next year!

entry.title: Best approach to migrate 1M Customers & Vendors from ECC to BP in S/4HANA – DMC vs CVI?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are preparing a migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA and we have approx. 1 million customer and vendor records that must be converted to Business Partners (BP).

We are evaluating the best migration approach and would like input from the community:

Has anyone successfully migrated a very large volume of customers and vendors directly via Data Migration Cockpit (DMC)?

Has anyone enabled CVI (Customer Vendor Integration) in ECC first, converted the master data there, and then migrated only balances / open items to S/4HANA?

For high volumes (1M+ business partners), what is the recommended best practice according to your experience?

Key questions we are trying to answer:

Is it more stable to activate CVI in ECC and synchronize customers/vendors to BP before the migration?

Does DMC scale efficiently for this volume of business partner creation?

Any lessons learned, performance considerations, or pitfalls to avoid?

Any guidance, experience sharing, or official SAP recommendations would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Net price condition type for Intercompany billing
entry.content:
Hi

- Create identical condition types in SD side and assign them to the pricing procedure.

- In copy control VTFL, make the Price Source A - Purchase Order and make the pricing type G to copy price elements unchanged while determining tax.

This way you can get the same value in the billing side.

If you have specific posting requirements, like posting the intercompany markup to an account different from inventory account during GR then you should do more things in both MM and SD pricing procedure. However, your question is not asking for those complex scenarios.

entry.title: Multiple Questions Regarding SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Features for Japanese Manufacturing Company
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,
We are currently implementing SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for a Japanese manufacturing company and have several questions regarding standard functionality. We would appreciate your guidance on the following points:

1. ISO20022 Format Support for Foreign Remittance
We currently output remittance data and upload it to the bank's web banking system for foreign payments.

Question: Does the remittance data output support ISO20022 format?


2. Manufacturing Cost Report (Cost of Goods Manufactured Statement)

Question: Is it possible to output a Manufacturing Cost Report as a standard feature?
If not available as standard, what alternative solutions would you recommend (e.g., custom reports, SAP Analytics Cloud, API integration)?


3. Financial Statements Operation for Japanese Companies
We need to understand best practices and localization support for Japanese accounting requirements.
Questions:

Are there Japanese-localized versions of standard financial statements available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?
How do other Japanese companies typically operate financial statements, including configuration, output methods, and workflows for the following:

Balance Sheet (BS)
Profit & Loss Statement (PL)
Journal Entries (仕訳帳)
General Ledger (総勘定元帳)
Other required financial statements for Japanese GAAP compliance

 


4. Customer Invoice Creation - Transaction Date and PDF Attachment
Regarding customer invoice creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:
① Actual Transaction Date

Current situation (SAP ECC): We can only retrieve and output the "invoice issue date" (document date), not the actual transaction date
Desired requirement: We need to retrieve and output the actual transaction date (the date when the transaction occurred) on customer invoices
This is required under the accrual basis accounting principle
Question: Is it possible to capture and output the actual transaction date in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

② PDF Document Storage

Question: Can SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud store, manage, and output invoice PDF files as supporting documents/proof of transaction?


Any guidance, documentation links, or best practice recommendations would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your support.
Best regards,

entry.title: Preliminary What’s New Information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3
entry.content:
Preliminary versions of the What’s New information and of the Product Assistance are now available for customers and partners to get a preview of the upcoming new and changed features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3.

You can find this preview on the current SAP Help Portal page SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (see What’s New section “Preview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3”). To access the Preliminary What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer or the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool.

The RASD tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view of What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The preliminary information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3 will be available in RASD within the next few days. We recommend using RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you. A valid S-User ID is needed to use the RASD tool and to view all the preliminary content stated above.

For any feedback you may have, try the Commenting Feature for What's New documentation in this release. See this blog for more information.

entry.title: Re: EWM RF Back Problem
entry.content:
Perhaps you can find some hints in a previous Blog / Question : Disable "Auto Enter" feature on RF device by deliv... - SAP Community

Regardless of the (Custom)Message, you could test with class "CL_RF_BLL_SRVC" :

/scwm/cl_rf_bll_srvc=>set_prmod( '2' ).       "Keep running Foreground
/scwm/cl_rf_bll_srvc=>set_fcode( '<fcode>' ). "Your desired FCODE

Hope this helps

Nic T.

entry.title: Re: BSEG-LZBKZ, Program RFAWVZ40 in S/4HANA Public Cloud?
entry.content:
Good day @djwafelap 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Foreign Trade Reporting (Germany), Foreign Trade Declarations

Reporting for German Foreign Trade Regulations

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e2d057b7b4df44ba941a040d4dda2956/aef9675712808467e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

To summarise, in public cloud, the old FRAWVZ40 process and LZB indicator maintenance are obsolete. It has been replaced by new Fiori-based process and XML submission service. You cannot manually maintain or substitute the LZB field in invoice or validations. This restriction is based on the clean-core approach used in public cloud.

Instead, SAP has delivered a revised reporting architecture under the German Localisation for Foreign Trade Regulation. See references for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Company code currency change
entry.content:
Hi All,

We have a company currently operating in Hungarian forints. HUF is maintained as company currency on set of books level. Our customer is about to change the company currency and operate in EUR. The problem is, even though they change the company currency to EUR, VAT reports and all relevant statutory reporting must be carried out in HUF based on valid legislation.

If the company currency is the same as in any other documents (customer or supplier invoices for example), then no exchange rate is displayed on journal entries. However we need to have somewhere in the system the values converted to HUF, so we can report transactions in local HUF currency.

Does anyone have experience with such a situation?

How can this be handled in terms of SAP Business ByDesing? Simple company code currency change in set of books will mean that we will only see values in EUR in the system.

Is there anything similar to double posting? Is there a way how to have the same posting in both currencies?

Could someone please advise me on this process?

Thanks in advance

Zuzana Geršiová

entry.title: Re: SE16N value unconverted is empty.
entry.content:
Did you insert correct data in the database table, did you respect the expected internal format

  • Use of CONVERSION_EXIT_LENUM_INPUT was required to format an external format to internal format in your case
  • e.g.  your '590311008' with trailing space would have raised a WRONG_LENGTH error (when a '0590311008' would have been converted to '00000000000590311008')

entry.title: Clarification Needed: How SAP CPM Risk Management Determines Positive vs. Negative Impact Values
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm working with the Risk Management module in SAP Commercial Project Management (CPM) and have a question regarding how the system handles impact values for Risks and Opportunities.

Scenario:

Under Risk Impact configuration, I’ve defined values for:

  • Cost
  • Schedule
  • Scope
  • Quality

Each of these has both positive and negative values configured.

Observation:

  • When I register a Risk in the Fiori app, the system only shows the negative values.
  • When I register an Opportunity, it only shows the positive values.

Question:

How does the system determine which values to show? Where is this behavior defined?

From what I’ve gathered:

  • The values are configured with positive or negative signs in simg > commercial project management > Master Data > Risk Management > Define risk Impact 
  • The system seems to filter based on the sign of the value and the type of record (Risk vs. Opportunity).
  • However, I couldn’t find a specific SPRO configuration node or BAdI that controls this logic.

Is this behavior hardcoded in the Fiori app or backend logic?
Are there any enhancement points or customizing options to influence this filtering?

Any insights or documentation references would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance,
Febin DS

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026 – Save the Date!

SAP Inside Track FORTALEZA will have its seventh edition on October 31, 2026.

The event is held in several countries worldwide. Its organizers are active members of the SAP Community, sharing knowledge and strengthening professional development among participants.
The event has been held in several cities worldwide for over 15 years.

Learn more about how to hold your SAP Inside Track event in your city through this LINK.

We are thrilled to announce the SAP Inside Track Fortaleza edition, held at HOTEL MAREIRO BEIRA MAR, in Av Beira Mar, 2380 CEP 60.165-120, Meireles, on October 31th, 2026!

 

Following an incredible first edition last year, we’re gearing up for an even more exciting event next year. Get ready for cutting-edge discussions, deep dives into SAP innovations, and hands-on sessions on the most pressing topics in the SAP world.

Key Topics for 2026:

  • Brazilian Tax Changes and impacts on S/4 HANA
  • Adoption and Migration to S/4 HANA: Strategies, best practices, and lessons learned to make your journey smoother.
  • Instant Payments: How SAP is revolutionizing the payments landscape with faster and more secure transactions.
  • Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML): The future of AI in SAP, from automation to decision-making and beyond.
  • Low-Code/No-Code Development: Empowering business users and developer

Join us for an inspiring day filled with insights from industry experts, networking opportunities, and the latest SAP trends that will shape the future of your business. You won’t want to miss it!

Mark your calendars:
Date: October 31th, 2026
Location: Mareiro Beira Mar Hotel

Av Beira Mar, 2380 CEP 60.165-120, Meireles.

Fortaleza – Ceará – Brasil

Stay tuned for more details and registration info coming soon!

entry.title: Re: BILL TO & SHIP TO AS PER INDIAN GST- ERROR IN SALES O...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the GST tax code determination logic is driven by standard configuration that prioritizes the customer’s region and plant location—leading to IGST being applied even in real estate scenarios where CGST + SGST should be used. Creating a dummy Ship-To Party based on property location alone may not override this logic unless additional configuration is aligned.

SAP’s standard GST configuration in Public Cloud uses the following logic for tax determination:

  • Interstate supply (IGST) is applied when the plant state ≠ customer state.
  • Intrastate supply (CGST + SGST) is applied when plant state = customer state.

However, Indian GST law for real estate mandates that place of supply is based on the location of the immovable property, not the buyer or supplier. This legal nuance is not automatically handled by SAP’s default logic.

Even though you created a Ship-To Party in Uttar Pradesh and assigned it to the customer in West Bengal, SAP may still be using the Sold-To Party’s region or the default tax determination logic. The partner function assignment might not be influencing the tax condition as expected. The pricing procedure or condition record may still be referencing the Sold-To Party or plant region.

Recommended approaches are

Ensure that the departure country/region in the tax determination procedure reflects the property location. You may need to customize the tax condition logic to prioritize Ship-To Party’s region.

Use condition tables that include Ship-To Party region, Material group for example Real Estate, Plant region. Adjust the access sequence for the tax condition to prioritize these fields.

Assign appropriate tax classification to the dummy Ship-To Party. Ensure that the classification reflects intrastate supply.

SAP may offer India GST localization enhancements in Public Cloud editions. Check if property-based place of supply logic is supported via configuration or extensibility.

entry.title: Re: Destination Bin and Destination Handling Unit in WPT...
entry.content:
Good day @Charisma_fitra 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Configuration for Putaway, Extended Warehouse Management, Direct and Combined Storage Control (Stock Removal)

To summarise, in public cloud, both the Destination Bin and Destination Handling Unit (HU) for warehouse tasks are managed by the EWM determination logic rather than manual configuration tables like in on-premise.

You cannot directly modify or script the bin in HU assignment logic through custom code. Instead, you can configure this behaviour by using EWM master data and determination setting via the Fiori configuration apps (SSCUI and manage Your Solution). To do so:

  • First, define Storage Type search Sequence for Putaway.
  • Second, assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence.
  • Finally, Define Putaway Control Indicator.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: 2H 2025- Automatic Holiday recalculation.
entry.content:
In the latest 2H 2025 release, an automatic holiday calendar update feature has been introduced.
Despite having the configurations set up correctly, certain scenarios are still not functioning as expected. For instance, when the start and end dates of a leave request fall on the same holiday, the leave is not being cancelled automatically.

Could you please advise if there are any additional configuration steps required or alternative approaches to resolve this issue?

entry.title: Application Adapters vs. HTTP Adapter: Choosing the Smarter Path for Your Integrations in SAP CI
entry.content:
The Real Story Behind Application Adapters vs. HTTP Adapter

In this blog, I’ll try to address one of the most common questions I’ve seen coming from the integration community:
“Why should we use an application-specific adapter when the HTTP adapter can connect to almost any system?”

It’s a great question — and one that often comes up when teams are designing integrations in SAP Cloud Integration. While both adapters help connect systems and exchange data, their purpose, capability, and long-term impact are very different.

Let’s dive in to understand how these two compare — and why, for most enterprise scenarios, the Application Adapter turns out to be the smarter choice.

Connectivity forms the backbone of every integration.

Whether it’s two systems within an organization or a network of applications spread across the cloud, everything begins with one simple need — to connect and communicate reliably.

In SAP Integration Suite, adapters serve as the bridges that enable this communication. They define how systems interact — the protocols, formats, and authentication methods involved.

Among them, the HTTP Adapter often stands out as the most flexible one. It’s capable of connecting with almost any API (Open AI, Salesforce, Anaplan, Coupa etc), giving developers the freedom to design integrations exactly the way they want.

But that very flexibility can become challenging over time.
As integrations scale, what once felt like full control can turn into complexity — with custom authentication handling, token management, pagination logic, and error-handling scripts piling up.

That’s usually the point where teams begin to realize that not all adapters are created equal.
Because while the HTTP Adapter gives you the freedom to build, the Application Adapter gives you the intelligence to build faster, cleaner, and with far less maintenance.

The HTTP Adapter is built for possibility — offering you the building blocks.
The Application Adapter is built for productivity — offering you ready-made intelligence, structure, and maintenance ease.

So, let’s unpack the difference — and see why the Application Adapter often wins when building scalable, enterprise-grade integrations.

1. Configuration & Setup – From Effort to Efficiency

  • HTTP Adapter: Every API call means you must manually configure authentication, endpoint URLs, headers, and payload structure. If the API changes, your configurations or the iFlow must change too.
  • Application Adapter: Comes pre-configured for that specific platform — including authentication type, API endpoints, pagination handling, and response structure.

This drastically reduces setup time — from weeks to just a couple of days.

2. Authentication – From Custom Coding to Built-In Security

  • HTTP Adapter: You need to manually build authentication logic — whether it’s OAuth 2.0, Basic Auth, API keys, or token refresh. This often involves extra Groovy scripts or header configurations to manage tokens and expiration.
  • Application Adapter: Provides in-built authentication mechanisms aligned with how the application itself authenticates. Whether it’s Salesforce OAuth, or ServiceNow Basic Auth, the adapter manages token exchange, refresh, and renewal automatically. 

No more custom scripts or manual token management — security is built-in and standardized.

3. Error Handling – From Raw to Readable

  • HTTP Adapter: Returns raw HTTP responses — cryptic 400/500 codes that need custom designing or mappings for error parsing.
  • Application Adapter: Provides structured, actionable errors that are already interpreted and categorized for you.

Less time deciphering API errors, more time focusing on business logic.

4. API Updates & Maintenance – From Manual to Managed

  • HTTP Adapter: When an API version changes (and they often do), you must manually update URLs, schemas, and logic — across every iFlow that uses it.
  • Application Adapter: SAP automatically manages these updates in the adapter.

No code changes, no re-deployment — maintenance burden drops dramatically.

5. Documentation & Testing – From Guesswork to Built-In

  • HTTP Adapter: You rely on external API documentation, and every change requires custom test flows to validate connectivity.
  • Application Adapter: Provides built-in documentation, predefined operation descriptions, and connection testing directly within the adapter configuration.

Testing and validation become part of configuration, not an afterthought.

6. SAP Ecosystem Support – From Standalone to Seamless

  • HTTP Adapter: While powerful, it’s a generic connector. Any issue typically requires troubleshooting at API level.
  • Application Adapter: Is natively supported by SAP, meaning if something doesn’t work, you get direct SAP support, not “ask the API vendor.”

Peace of mind and faster issue resolution.

7. Performance, Pagination & Security – From Custom Code to Standardization

  • HTTP Adapter: You need custom logic for pagination, token refresh, or retry policies.
  • Application Adapter: Already includes smart handling for authentication, pagination, throttling, and error recovery.

One less thing to code, debug, and maintain.

8. Cost of Ownership – From Rework to Reuse

A generic HTTP-based integration might seem faster at first for a simple proof-of-concept. But as your API landscape scales, every new API = more custom code = more effort to maintain.
On the other hand, Application Adapters are built for reuse, auto-updated, and ready for scale.

Over time, the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) is significantly lower with Application Adapters.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When to Still Use the HTTP Adapter

Of course, the HTTP Adapter still has its place — especially when:

  • You’re integrating with niche systems without a native adapter.
  • You need to handle non-standard API behaviors.
  • You require advanced custom logic not covered by the application adapter.

But once SAP offers an Application Adapter for your API, using it is a no-brainer — it’s about speed, resilience, and long-term maintainability.

Conclusion

In a world where integrations evolve rapidly, application adapters bring the intelligence back into integration — not just by connecting systems, but by simplifying, standardizing, and future-proofing your integration landscape.

So next time you wonder “Why not just use HTTP?” — remember:
Because in enterprise integration, simplicity isn’t about doing less — it’s about doing smarter.

 

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith Oswal

entry.title: Hello, to use Active Competencies from TIH with Inactive Attribute Type in 360 Review Forms?
entry.content:
Hello,
We would like to confirm the suitability and potential risks of a customization we intend to implement in the production environment. Our goal is to create a 360 Review Form where the ratable Custom Sections are composed of Active Competencies maintained in the Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH). However, we do not want these Competencies to appear in the Growth Portfolio. To achieve this, we tested a scenario in the preview environment where we:

  • Kept all required Competencies active in TIH.
  • Set the “Competency” Attribute Type to Inactive to prevent them from being visible in Growth Portfolio.  

In our test, the results were as follows:

  • The Competency Attribute Type did not appear in the Growth Portfolio (as intended).
  • All Competencies mapped in the 360 template XML were successfully brought into the 360 Review Form upon launch.
  • Ratings are not connected with the Growth Portfolio or other TIH-related modules, which aligns with our intentions.

Before we apply this approach in production, we would like to confirm:

  1. Could this configuration (using active competencies under an inactive “Competency” Attribute Type) cause any functional issues in the future?
  2. Is there any known risk related to data integrity, future upgrades, or Talent Intelligence Hub synchronization?
  3. Do you have other recommendations or solutions on how to implement our desired outcome?

We have also attached a few screenshots to better illustrate our current configuration and the intended workaround solution. 
Thank you very much for your support and guidance.

entry.title: Subject: Tracking Disabled in SAP Enable Now – Request for Data Recovery
entry.content:
Hello,

After several months without access to tracking in SAP Enable Now, I recently restored my permissions and can now view the associated functionalities.
However, I have noticed that tracking appears to have been disabled: all activity reports for lessons (completed/passed/results/attempts) show null values.

This affects the following workarea:
🔗 https://la-poste.enable-now.cloud.sap/#wa/overview/wa!Coeur_Finance

And courses such as this one, assigned to learners:
🔗 https://la-poste.enable-now.cloud.sap/#learner/C_B475D232F102494B8752ECE1D35CD293

These contents are simulation-based courses (Exercise/Practice), stored in folders assigned to the “Learners” population.

It seems that tracking was not activated centrally in SAP earlier this year, as reports were unavailable until September. As a result, all historical data prior to that period appears to be missing.

Could you confirm if these historical activity records (from May 2025 onwards) still exist and help us recover them?
If the data is available, please advise on how we can retrieve it.

Thank you in advance for your assistance.
Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Integrações com APIs via SPROXY no Cenário ABAP/PI: Um Guia Prático para Desenvolvedores SAP
entry.content: Muito interessante, parabéns pelo conteúdo.  👏

entry.title: Re: clean core proxy isn't commited
entry.content: The only solution I could find was to comment out the destination in the wrapper and perform a bapi_transaction_commit outside the wrapper.

entry.title: Re: STAUTHTRACE
entry.content:
Please check SAP-Note 2242714 - STAUTHTRACE: Display of access filtering - SAP for Me ...
Extract :

"You evaluate the system trace for authorization checks with transaction STAUTHTRACE. Following the implementation of SAP Note 2147808, trace entries are now also displayed that are written during the reading of authorizations of a user with the help of the function modules 'GET_AUTH_VALUES' and 'SUSR_USER_AUTH_FOR_OBJ_GET'.
However, for these trace entries, there is no marker that identifies the entry in question as being generated by access filtering instead of by the ABA language command "authority-check"."

"The authorization display has received a new access filtering column. If this field is selected, no authorization check is carried out with the language command "authority-check"; instead, access filtering is carried out.
Here, the authorizations of the user for the specified authorization object and the specified field values are read. These authorization values are used as additional filter conditions in the selection of business data so that the user only sees data for which he or she possesses the appropriate authorizations."

Hope this helps to clarify ...

Kind regards

Nic T.
